Abstract
The paper adjoins the book [PV] and turns to be, in a sense, its
continuation. In the book the varieties of representations had been
considered. In the matter of fact, the varieties under consideration
are action-type varieties. This paper studies other classes of representations, axiomatizable in the special action-type logic.

1

Background (preliminaries)

1.1

Variety Rep − K

Given a commutative with the unit ring K, consider a variety which is
also a category, denoted by Rep − K. The algebras of this variety are twosorted algebras. These algebras are pairs, or representations, (V, G), where
V is K-module and G a group, acting in V . The action is treated as an
operation in the two-sorted algebra (V, G).
The axioms are as follows:
• 1. the mapping a → a ◦ g is a K-linear mapping in V ,
• 2. (a ◦ g1 ) ◦ g2 = a ◦ g1 g2 ,
• 3. a ◦ 1 = a.

1

 Here 1 is the unit in G, a ∈ V, g ∈ G. The operation ◦ recovers the
representation ρ : G → AutV , which is sometimes identified with the algebra
(V, G), i.e., ρ = (V, G).
The pointed identities together with the identities of groups and Kmodules determine the variety Rep − K. As usual, this variety is also a
category. Its morphisms are two-sorted homomorphisms
μ = (α, β) : (V, G) → (V ′ , G′ ),
where α : V → V ′ a K-homomorphism of modules, β : G → G′ is a homomorphism of groups, and (a◦g)α = aα ◦g β . We have: Kerμ = (Kerα, Kerβ).
Take Kerα = V0 , Kerβ = H. Then the pair (V0 , H) is a congruence of the
representation (V, G) in the following sense: V0 is a submodule in V , invariant under the action of the group G, H is a normal subgroup in G, acting
trivially in V /V0 . We have (V, G)/Kerμ = (V /V0 , G/H). This gives the
theorem on homomorphisms.
Let us consider a free representation W = W (X, Y ) Here the pair (X, Y )
is a two-sorted set. We have: W (X, Y ) = (XKF (Y ), F (Y )), where F (Y ) =
F is a free group over the set Y , XKF = Φ is a free KF -module over the
set X and KF is a group algebra.
The elements of Φ have the form w = x1 u1 + ... + xn un , ui ∈ KF ; the
elements of F are written as f = f (y1 , ..., ym ). The action ◦ is defined by the
rule:
w ◦ f = wf = x1 (u1 f ) + ... + xn (un f ).
It is easy to understand that the mappings α : X → V and β : Y → G
determine the homomorphism μ = (α, β) : (Φ, F ) = W → (V, G).
Consider further the sets Hom(W, ρ) = Hom(W, (V, G)). In the situation
of the finite X = {x1 , ..., xn } and Y = {y1 , ..., ym} the sets Hom(W, ρ) are
treated as affine spaces. There is a natural bijection Hom(W, ρ) → V (n) ×
G(m) . A point

ai ∈ V, gk ∈ G, corresponds to the homomorphism μ = (α, β) : (Φ, F ) →
(V, G).

 1.2

Logic in Rep − K.

Given X and Y , consider a signature
L = LX,Y = {∨, ∧, ¬, ∃x, ∃y, x ∈ X, y ∈ Y }.
For the algebra W = W (X, Y ) we consider equalities w ≡ 0 and f ≡ 1. We
treat these equalities as logical formulas. The equalities of the first kind we
call action-type equalities, while the equalities of the second type we call group
equalities. Denote by LW = LX,Y W (X, Y ) the absolutely free L-algebra over
the set of all W -equalities. Its elements we call formulas (elementary, first
order formulas) over the free representation W = (Φ, F ).
Let us consider an example of L-algebra. Take the set Hom(W, (V, G)).
Let Set(W, (V, G)) be a system of all subsets of Hom(W, (V, G)). It is clear,
that boolean operations are defined in Set(W, (V, G)) and it is a boolean
algebra. Let us define also quantifiers. Let A be a subset of Hom(W, (V, G)).
We set: μ(α, β) ∈ ∃xA, if there exists ν = (α′ , β) such that ν ∈ A and
α(x1 ) = α′ (x1 ) for x1 6= x. Analogously we define ∃yA. Here ∃x and ∃y are
quantifiers of the boolean algebra Set(W, (V, G)) in the sense of the following
definition.
The quantifier ∃ of a boolean algebra B is a mapping ∃ : B → B with
the properties:
• 1. ∃0 = 0,
• 2. a < ∃a,
• 3. ∃(a ∧ ∃b) = ∃a ∧ ∃b.
Here 0 is a zero in B, and a, b ∈ B. Define now a canonical homomorphism
of L-algebras

if f β = 1 in G. Since LW is free, this determines V al(u) for every formula

Define further separately the logic of action (action-type logic). It is generated by equalities of action w ≡ 0 in the signature LX = {∨, ∧, ¬, ∃x, x ∈
X}. There are no quantifiers ∃y and equalities f ≡ 1. Denote this logic by

 1.3

Classes of representations

Consider classes X of representations (V, G) in Rep − K and, simultaneously, the sets of formulas T in the logic LW with countable X and Y . We
establish Galois correspondence
T = X∗ = {u ∈ LW | u holds in every (V, G) ∈ X}
X = T ∗ = {(V, G)| every formula from T holds in (V, G)}.
A class X of the kind X = T ∗ is called axiomatizable one. Here T is an
arbitrary set. If T consists of action-type formulas, then X = T ∗ is an
action-type axiomatizable class.
Let us distinguish special cases.
1. T consists of equalities. Then X = T ∗ is a variety of representations.
If T consists of action-type equalities, then X = T ∗ is an action-type variety.
Such X is given also by the formulas of the form x ◦ u ≡ 0, u ∈ KF .
2. Formulas of the kind u1 ∨ u2 ∨ . . . ∨ un , where all ui are equalities, are
called pseudo-equalities (or pseudo-identities). The corresponding X = T ∗
are called pseudo-varieties. Action-type pseudo-varieties are given by the
formulas of the w1 ≡ 0 ∨ . . . ∨ wn ≡ 0 kind.
3. Formulas of the kind u1 ∧u2 ∧. . .∧un =⇒ u, where all ui are equalities,
are called quasi-equalities (or quasi-identities). Formulas w1 ≡ 0 ∧ . . . ∧ wn ≡
0 =⇒ w ≡ 0 is an action-type quasi-identity. We have quasi-varieties and
action-type quasi-varieties.
4. Universal formulas have the form u1 ∨ . . . ∨ un ∨ ¬v1 ∨ . . . ∨ ¬vm
where ui and vj are equalities. Universal action-type formulas have the form
′
w1 ≡ 0 ∨ . . . ∨ wn ≡ 0 ∨ w1′ 6≡ 0 ∨ . . . ∨ wm
6≡ 0. The corresponding classes
X are universal classes and action-type universal classes. We consider also
classes X, axiomatizable by arbitrary action-type formulas.
A class X we call a saturated one if the inclusion (V, G) ∈ X holds if and
only if for the corresponding faithful representation (V, G) holds (V, G) ∈ X.
A class X we call a right-hereditary one, if (V, G) ∈ X =⇒ (V, H) ∈ X
holds for every subgroup H in G.
Finally, class of representations X is called a right-local one, if (V, G) ∈ X
holds if all (V, H) belong to X, where H are finitary-generated subgroups in
G.

Problem 1. Is it true that an axiomatized class X is action-type axiomatized
if and only if it is saturated, right-hereditary and right-local?
Theorem 2.1 solves the question in one direction, but the opposite claim
requires additional considerations.

Using all this, prove the theorem for quasivarieties. Let us prove that if
X is a saturated, right-hereditary and right-local quasivariety, then this X is
an action-type quasivariety.
As earlier, select the following two items of the proof. Check first of all
that if X satisfies the pointed closure conditions, then X is a quasivariety if
and only if every layer XG is a quasivariety. Then using the layer XF and closure conditions, prove that the class X is determined by action-type quasivarieties. The first item of the proof copies the one for pseudo-varieties with the
only difference that we work with filtered products instead of cartesian and
ultra-products. The second item follows the idea used for pseudo-varieties.
The same reasoning with two items we use for universal classes. Now the
theorem 2.2 is proved.

3
3.1

General theorem
Some general considerations

In the previous theorem we used the fact that if the class X is given by
axioms of a special kind, then every layer XG is determined by the axioms
of the same kind as well. However we cannot say anything similar if the
type of the axioms is not fixed. We cannot claim, that if the class X is
axiomatized and meets the demanded closure conditions, then the layer XF
is also axiomatized. We will study this obstacle later on.
Let us note that it is convenient to use the following terminology. We call
a class X strictly saturated if it is saturated, right-hereditary and right-local.

3.2

The theorem

Theorem 3. Let X be an axiomatized class of representations and a layer
XF also axiomatized. Such X is action-type axiomatized if and only if it is
strictly saturated.
